results.title: Quest for country (A)
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley, Rachel Perkins and Blackfella Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “From spirit to spirit (A)”.
This program expresses the spiritual and physical catharsis of an Aboriginal man from the urban environment. Michael Riley gives an insight into the indigenous view of white society and highlights the problems which non-Aboriginal people may have in understanding this attitude as well as the difficulties Aboriginal people may have in explaining it.

results.title: Passing through
results.brief_description: A young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past?
results.description: A young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past?

results.title: Mungo lady (A)
results.creator_credit: Mari Bennett, Rachel Perkins and Blackfella Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “From spirit to spirit (A)”.
In 1960 the remains of an Aboriginal woman were exhumed at Lake Mungo, NSW by the white anthropologist/archaeologist, Alan Thorne. The woman had been cremated at least 25,000 years ago, providing the first evidence of this practice, and evidence for elaborate funerary customs by Aborigines in pre-historic times. The remains were exhibited around the world, before being returned to the Aborigines in 1990. This program takes a look at this incident from an Aboriginal perspective.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mari Bennett, Rachel Perkins and Blackfella Films

results.title: Black chicks talking [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: Leah Purcell, Bain Stewart, SBS Independent and BungaburBungabura Productions
results.brief_description: Performer and writer Leah Purcell talks with five very different Indigenous women - Rosanna Angus, Kathryn Hay, Deborah Mailman, Cilla Malone and Tammy Williams - about what it means to be Aboriginal in Australia today. In a series of individual interviews and at one lively dinner party, the women frankly share their life experiences and opinions. Though their backgrounds are extremely diverse, common themes of culture, family, racism and denial run through their stories, as does the ongoing personal and social legacy of past government polices of forced removal. The result is a passionate and challenging exploration of black identity. Teachers notes available through Film Australia at: http://www.filmaust.com.au/programs/default.asp?content=teachers_notes

results.title: The Road home
results.creator_credit: Robert Nugent, Kelrick Martin and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Documentary about Roy Read who was raised an orphan and told he wasn’t Aboriginal - just “darker than others”. At Kinchela Boys’ Home he was subjected to the horrors of institutionalised life. Now 49 years later, he returns to face the demons of his past - and reconnect with the family he never knew he had. Contains archival b&w stills

results.title: The Bus trip
results.brief_description: Ever gone on a trip and thought that maybe you left the oven on at home? In this entertaining film these kinds of speculations turn a simple cross country bus trip into a nightmare. Original Format 35mm/colour.

results.title: Your brother, my tidda
results.creator_credit: Kathy Sport, Kelrick Martin and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
“Coming out” to family, living with HIV and religion - some of the life changing situations faced by two Aboriginal gay men, Sam Barsah and Aaron Clark.
Sam has “come out” twice; first to his family about his sexuality and then about his HIV status. Like other indigenous gay men, he wants respect and understanding and only now, almost ten years later, does he feel able to speak openly about his story. Aaron is young and relatively new to Sydney. Growing up as a Jehovah’s Witness, he is looking for an alternative gay Christian group.
Using a contemporary blend of semi-observational filming, photos and animation, this short documentary about race and sexuality describes two very different stories of being Aboriginal and gay.
N.B. “Tidda” is an Aboriginal word for “sister”.

results.title: After Mabo (A)
results.creator_credit: John Hughes, Debra Annear, Richard Frankland and Mirimbiak Nations Aboriginal Corporation
results.brief_description: Filmed over a ten-month period throughout Australia, this probing documentary examines the political controversy surrounding Native Title and the Australian Federal Governments proposed amendments to the Native Title Act, 1993. It follows the Indigenous representatives in their attempt to fight the amendments in the media, in the bush, and in the halls of Parliament House, Canberra. This video is ideally suited to students of history, politics and Aboriginal studies. NOTE: There are no discussion notes included with this title.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Hughes, Debra Annear, Richard Frankland and Mirimbiak Nations Aboriginal Corporation
results.description: Filmed over a ten-month period throughout Australia, this probing documentary examines the political controversy surrounding Native Title and the Australian Federal Governments proposed amendments to the Native Title Act, 1993. It follows the Indigenous representatives in their attempt to fight the amendments in the media, in the bush, and in the halls of Parliament House, Canberra. This video is ideally suited to students of history, politics and Aboriginal studies. NOTE: There are no discussion notes included with this title.

results.title: Songlines: contemporary aboriginal music (A)
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Introduction to the Music Industry. Module 4.6. Contemporary Australian Aboriginal music has become an international presence in recent years. This program profiles artists who have taken their brand of indigenous music to the world: Yothu Yindi, Archie Roach and Tiddas. Traditional elements are incorporated into contemporary styles. This is not simply a matter of throwing in the odd didjeridu and clap stick, but rather the traditional cultural role of Aboriginal music as an educational medium is maintained and extended to cover new, important issues and themes.

results.title: Dusty hearts
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Mariel Beros and Pauline Chan
results.brief_description: Sax Elthan is a hapless musician, a refugee from the inner city. Rejected by his girlfriend, he travels to the outback to look for work. One burning Wednesday he finds himself beside a highway, waiting for a lift, contemplating his future. It arrives in the shape of a beat-up Volkswagon with a wardrobe tied to the roof. A black comedy about one man’s destiny starring Geoff Morrell (Blue Heelers, Changi). Also features Tina Bursill.
